leitej.crypto.symmetric

Enum PBEEnum

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.lang.Enum<PBEEnum>
      • leitej.crypto.symmetric.PBEEnum
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Comparable<PBEEnum>

    public enum PBEEnum
extends java.lang.Enum<PBEEnum>
    Password-based encryption (PBE).

    PBE mechanisms are based on cryptographic hashing mechanisms. In essence, a password and a salt, which is just random data, is fed in some fashion into a mixing function based around a secure hash and the function is applied the number of times dictated by an iteration count. Once the mixing is complete, the resulting byte stream coming out of the PBE mechanism is used to create the key for the cipher to be used and possibly an initialisation vector as well.

    The most widespread PBE mechanisms are published in PKCS #5 and PKCS #12. There is also a PBE scheme that can be used with S/MIME, which is published in RFC 3211. In the latter case, the key generated from the password is used to generate another key.
    Author:
    Julio Leite

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static class  PBEEnum.IterationCountEnum
      Iteration count is a public value - as in you should assume an attacker can find it.

      The sole purpose of the iteration count is to increase the computation time required to convert a password to a key.

      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      java.lang.String getName()
      PBE mechanisms are named using the rule PBEwithAnd where function is the algorithm (usually an hash) used to support the mechanism that generates the key and cipher is the underlying cipher used for the encryption.
      int goodSaltByteSize()
      The salt is a public value - as in you should assume an attacker can find it.

      The reason for the salt is that by adding a string of random bytes to the password, the same password can be used as a source for a large number of different keys.

      • getName

        public java.lang.String getName()
        PBE mechanisms are named using the rule PBEwithAnd where function is the algorithm (usually an hash) used to support the mechanism that generates the key and cipher is the underlying cipher used for the encryption.
        Returns:

      • goodSaltByteSize

        public int goodSaltByteSize()
        The salt is a public value - as in you should assume an attacker can find it.

        The reason for the salt is that by adding a string of random bytes to the password, the same password can be used as a source for a large number of different keys. This is useful because it forces attackers to perform the key generation calculation every time they wish to try a password, for every piece of encrypted data they wish to attack.

        If you can, make the salt at least as large as the block size of the function used to process the password. Usually the block size of the function is the same as that of the underlying message digest used by it.
        Returns:
